title: You Are The Economy
actTitle: What Will You Do This Week?

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How does Riding a bicycle
affect the economy?
activitySet.option1: Bicycles and bicycle parts sales for the U.S. bicycle industry add up to over $6 billion yearly.
activitySet.option2: Bicycle repairers made on average $12.15 an hour (in 2012). There are just over 10,000 employed in the U.S.
activitySet.option2b: Source: U.S. Dept of Labor, BLS, Occupational Employment Statistics, 2012
activitySet.option3: There are over 4,000 bike shops in the United States, with just over $6 billion dollars in sales in 2012.
activitySet.option4: The annual cost of operating a bicycle is approximately $308 a year, less than the average monthly car payment.

activitySet.option1: Americans spend around $500 billion on clothes and shoes each month.
activitySet.option2: In 2010, the average household spent $1700 on apparel, footwear, and related products.
activitySet.option3: Employment in the U.S. apparel manufacturing industry has declined from about 900,000 jobs in 1990 to 150,000 in 2011.
activitySet.option4: Fashion accounts for roughly 39% of teen budgets.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How are schools a part
of the economy?
activitySet.option1: High-quality schools can increase the value of nearby homes.
activitySet.option1b: Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis Review, May/June 2010
activitySet.option2: The average household with school age children spends more than $600 on back-to-school apparel, shoes, supplies, and electronics each year.
activitySet.option2b: Source: National Retail Federation with Prosper Insights & Analytics, 2013
activitySet.option3: Schools employ teachers, bus drivers, food service workers, facilities workers, healthcare workers, and many more.
activitySet.option4: Schools buy goods and services, such as textbooks, desks, computers, and whiteboards which add to the overall economy.

activitySet.option1: The average commute in 2009 was 11.8 miles and took 24 minutes.
activitySet.option2: Atlanta is the #1 airport in the world, with over 90 million passengers in 2012.
activitySet.option3: Transportation spending consumed 10% of the U.S. GDP in 2011.
activitySet.option4: Transportation and related industries employed 12,305,000 workers in 2011.

activitySet.option1: Americans spent $61.4 billion on their pets in 2011.
activitySet.option2: More than 65% of households have a pet.
activitySet.option3: In 2013, Americans spent an estimated $330 million on Halloween costumes for their pets.
activitySet.option4: Pet food and treat sales are more than $20 billion a year in the United States.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How is child care
a part of the economy?
activitySet.option1: In 2011, The average weekly cost of child care for families with employed mothers was $143.
activitySet.option2: In 2012, the U.S. has 1.3 million child care workers, with a median pay of $19,510.
activitySet.option2b: Source: U.S. Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics
activitySet.option3: The child care industry generated $47 billion in revenue in 2013.
activitySet.option4: The U.S. child care services industry includes about 53,000 commercial facilities plus about 21,000 facilities run by nonprofit organizations.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How is taking a vacation
a part of the economy?
activitySet.option1: Vacation travel in the U.S. accounts for around $600 billion in spending each year.
activitySet.option2: Small businesses in the United States employ more than half (53%) of the travel industry workforce, or 3.9 million workers.
activitySet.option3: One out of every 18 Americans works, either directly or indirectly, in a travel or tourism-related industry.
activitySet.option4: 3 out of 4 domestic trips are taken for leisure purposes (77%).

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How is eating in a restaurant
a part of the economy?
activitySet.option2: There were over 630,000 restaurants in the U.S. in 2013.
activitySet.option3: The U.S. employs just over 1 million restaurant cooks who earn an average of $11.20/hour.
activitySet.option4: Consumers spend 40% of their food costs on eating out.

activitySet.option1: More than 300,000 painters are employed in U.S. construction and maintenance.
activitySet.option2: Over 65 million gallons of house paint are sold in the U.S. every year.
activitySet.option3: The U.S. paint and coatings manufacturing industry has combined annual sales of about $22 billion. House paint represents about 40% of industry revenue.
activitySet.option4: In addition to construction and automotive, other industries that use paints and coatings include marine, wooden furniture, steel, and general industry.

activitySet.econoQuestion: How is soccer a part of the economy?
activitySet.option1: Annual registration of U.S. Youth Soccer players has grown from 103,432 in 1974 to 3,020,633 in 2012.
activitySet.option2: The expansion rights for the New York City MLS team were purchased for an estimated $100 million dollars.
activitySet.option3: It's estimated that at least 35 million kids between 5 and 18 currently play an organized sport each year in the U.S. Of that, 21 million are involved in non-school youth sports.
activitySet.option3b: Source: Minnesota Amateur Sports Commission, Athletic Footwear Association, USA Today
activitySet.option4: In 2012, an estimated 1.3 million children sustained a sports-related injury severe enough to send them to a hospital emergency room, at a total cost of $935 million-plus annually.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How does going to the movies
affect the economy?
activitySet.option1: For 2011, the gross output of the arts and culture sector of the U.S. economy was $916 billion.
activitySet.option2: In 2011, motion picture and video industry employed nearly 310,000 workers at $25 billion in compensation.
activitySet.option3: The U.S. has over 39,000 movie screens in 2012, according to the National Association of Theatre Owners.
activitySet.option4: Approximately 70% of all Americans go to the movies at least once every year.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How is golf a part of
the economy?
activitySet.option1: In 2011, Americans spent $5.6 billion on golf supplies.
activitySet.option2: In 2011, golf in the United States generated an estimated $68.8 billion of goods and services.
activitySet.option3: Golf courses employ grounds maintenance workers whose median pay is $23,970. Most do not need formal education for the job.
activitySet.option4: There were an estimated 463 million rounds of golf played in the U.S. in 2011.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How are video games a part
of the economy?
activitySet.option1: The U.S. games industry sold $20.7 billion in gaming systems, games, and accessories in 2012.
activitySet.option2: Approximately 6 computer and/or video games were sold on average every second of every day of 2012.
activitySet.option3: The global Mobile gaming revenue is estimated to reach $14.4 billion by 2017.
activitySet.option4: 51% of U.S. households own a dedicated game console and those who do, own an average of 2 consoles.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How is gardening a part
of the economy?
activitySet.option1: Lawn and garden equipment and supply stores in the United States employ over 140,000 people.
activitySet.option2: Americans spend more than $29 billion per year at lawn and garden stores.
activitySet.option3: Total annual sales at U.S. farmers' markets are estimated at $1 billion.
activitySet.option4: Nearly half of Americans have gardened within the last year.

activitySet.econoQuestion:
How does going to the doctor
affect the economy?
activitySet.option1: Americans spend more than $3 trillion on healthcare each year.
activitySet.option2: More than 1 billion insulin syringes and lancets are manufactured each year for use by diabetics.
activitySet.option3: Employment of physicians and surgeons is projected to grow 18% from 2012 to 2022, faster than the average for all occupations.
activitySet.option4: A 45-year-old worker earning $50,000 a year who suffers permanent disability, could lose $1,000,000 in future earnings.
